Award.AwardTitle: CNH-Ex: Synergies and Feedbacks Between Local Direct Democracy and Large-Scale Biodiversity Conservation Efforts
Award.AbstractNarration:
In much of the U.S., natural communities of native species remain largely within protected areas. The maintenance of biodiversity thus relies on how strongly native wildlife communities motivate conservation and on how effectively conservation protects wild communities. This project explores two major alternative mechanisms for this coupling between nature and society, the purchase of lands or rights by conservation organizations and legislation through ballot initiatives. Researchers will compare abundances of rare or threatened native plant species and abundances of introduced plants that tend to exclude native species in areas conserved through these different mechanisms. The study will also investigate the factors that determine whether different types of conservation actions are undertaken. The project will use California as the study system, since both mechanisms have been widely employed in the state, and a rich body of data is available. Results will inform conservation policy and help guide future protection of native species in and beyond California. Dissemination of findings will be enhanced by integration of the study with a program to bring conservation practitioners into classrooms and public forums. The project will also train undergraduate students, a Ph.D. student, and a postdoctoral researcher.

This project will examine how local landscape, community and ballot characteristics influence the probability of passage of conservation measures. Researchers will also evaluate the potential ancillary benefits of public initiatives in helping to safeguard biodiversity by protecting habitats that are important for priority species and by protecting priority ecosystems through a combination of GIS analyses and ecological field surveys. The project will contrast the contribution to conserving biodiversity of parcels protected through ballot measures with those protected through a more conventional protected area acquisition strategy. Finally, researchers will apply spatial optimization methods to evaluate how land conservation efforts undertaken by large-scale actors can complement those of local-scale actors more effectively in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When local communities decide to protect open spaces or encourage development projects they impact species by affecting habitat conversion. Often in the US these decisions are taken through a version of direct democracy. Specifically, communities vote at the ballot box on particular measures or initiatives that affect local land uses. They do so for many reasons, but in this project we focused on the consequences for biodiversity of the decisions that local communities take. We focused on counties and municipalities in California for our analyses.

We first examined what affected whether or not particular ballot measures pass. When doing so, we recognized that local ballot initiatives promote urban development as often as they restrict it helping to conserve habitat. We also recognized that ballot cards have a large number of different measures on them for voters to consider. We showed that if you want to understand where and why ballots pass, you need to think about the set of options that a single voter sees. This happens because whether a voter will support a measure that would curb urban growth depends on whether other growth limiting measures are also on the ballot. Interestingly, the same is not true for measures encouraging development.

As well as wanting to understand what led ballots to pass in particular areas, we also wanted to understand better how protected areas established with local ballot measures contributed to biodiversity conservation. Local communities protect areas of habitat using ballot initiatives for many reasons (recreation, improved local water quality, etc.). Even if they are established for other reasons, these sites might still be able to help society meet goals for biodiversity protection. When we compared the locations of protected areas established through local ballot initiatives with those established by large scale conservation actors (a state conservation agency and large land trust), we found that ballot protected sites they were quite geographically constrained. Most occurred in counties nearer to the coast and near to more developed urban areas. Helpfully though, these are exactly the places where additional protected areas are most needed. As a consequence, we found that despite being geographically constrained, ballot protected areas were in locations where they could make as important a contribution to biodiversity conservation as protected areas established by organizations working over larger scales.

We then conducted ecological surveys of some ballot protected areas and compared what we found to what we found to ecological conditions on nearby protected areas established by the state conservation agency. We were concerned that perhaps ballot protected areas, despite being in good locations for conservation, were more heavily used by local communities for recreation and perhaps less suitable for supporting other species or key habitats. But again, we found no evidence of this. Protected areas differ in how effectively they can protect species but the mechanism by which these areas were protected in the first place does not appear to be a key determining factor in their ecological condition. This is very encouraging. It means that the conservation contributions made by many, diverse local communities through the ballot should be taken into account when evaluating how well suited our protected area networks are for conserving species or identifying where additional protection efforts might be most needed.

Finally, to illustrate how this could be done, we developed computer algorithms that federal or state agencies or large NGOs could use to help them target future investments in land protection. These algorithms combine data on where species are found, what land costs and other factors to try to identify sets of sites that offers a particularly cost effective way of expanding existing protected areas to achieve biodiversity protection goals. In an advance over past attempts, we showed how a conservation planner could think ahead about what future changes to land use might be coming when deciding where to invest in further habitat protection. This addition provided a means for us to account for potential future land use decisions by local communities, whether to protect more habitat or allow more development. These new tools will provide a means to help large-scale conservation organizations to complement and support the efforts of local communities more effectively.

The project supported two post-docs / early career researchers, a PhD student, a Masters student and four undergraduate researchers. It supported a range of other educational activities, such as bringing conservation professionals into undergraduate classrooms to meet with students. In addition, project staff were able to organize and lead major symposia, working groups and poster sessions helping to build the community of researchers interested in these topics, who come from a wide range of disciplines. Project staff were also invited to participate in a major federal study examining the value of public land. The research team also shared results and products with conservation practitioners active in land protection.
